div.head: To my Worthy Friend, Monsieur de Gray, upon his exquisite piece of Horsemanship and Ferriery.
div.l: WHen Troy's Palladium, on whose fatall stay
Their fortunes, hopes, their Gods, their Altars lay;
Was by Vlysses cunning hand surpriz'd,
And Pallas woo'd to see Troy sacrific'd:
A Horse, whose entrals that vast City burne.
How different is thy Gift, since here we see
Pleasure with safety, strength with wit agree?
This frame exceeds that; but to nobler ends,
That hurts by fraud, by knowledge this defends:
And though in Ilium's Horse an Army rest,
'Twill be far more to COMPREHEND this Beast;
Since Ignorance hath taught our Ile to lay
Her Art, on Iades that onely runne away.
But when I looke on thine, and there behold
Souldiers made knowing, and the knowing bold:
I cry, had this been given for that of Wood,
Minerva had return'd, and Ilium stood.
